'speaker_5': 'Thank you. I'm going to start and end my remarks with thanks. I want to first thank the Fair Coalition. The voices of people with lived experiences have been very important to the development and passage of this legislation. We all know that one in three people in Seattle have a criminal background, but the reality is that no matter'

'speaker_5': 'how many facts and figures exist, what actually creates structural change is our collective awareness of these lived experiences. They're worth more than all of the studies combined, and it takes incredible courage to speak in public about one's experience with the criminal justice system.'

'speaker_5': 'And I want to acknowledge and honor those who have. You have humbled me, and we are here today because of your courage. The legislation before the council today was developed collaboratively over the past year through a stakeholder process that included renters, landlords, advocates, the Office of Mayor Ed Murray and the Office of Civil Rights.'

'speaker_5': 'The bill the bill was considered in my committee at four different meetings, including a stakeholder discussion and evening forum highlighting feedback from formerly incarcerated people, tenants, advocacy organizations, the Rental Housing Association and the Washington Multifamily Housing Association. Before that process, it was a recommendation of memories, housing affordability and livability agenda in 2015, and even before that, in'

'speaker_5': '2013, it was an issue that Councilmember O'Brien Laquita had spearheaded with the Office of Housing, focusing on the housing providers that receive city funds to ensure that they're removing barriers to housing funded with city taxpayer dollars. The Civil Rights Utilities Economic Development Arts Committee last week recommended approval of their Fair Chance housing ordinance by a60 vote.'

'speaker_5': 'The legislation, sponsored by myself and Council President Harrell, prohibits landlords from screening applicants based on past arrests or criminal convictions. This ordinance would prevent landlords from screening screening applicants based on criminal convictions, arrests that did not lead to conviction, convictions that have been expunged, vacated or sealed juvenile records.'

'speaker_5': 'The bill also prohibits the use of advertising language that categorically excludes people with arrests or conviction records. The legislation does not apply to people registered as sex offenders who committed their crime as an adult. Landlords will still be able to screen applicants based on employment, credit scores, income ratios or other criteria to ensure that people will be'

'speaker_5': 'good tenants. They'll merely be unable to use criminal history when considering applicants. Something no study has shown affects a person's ability to successfully be a good tenant or neighbor today, largely because of the new access to data that historically has been less accessibly accessible.'

'speaker_5': 'Landlords now can reject tenants because they've been harassed in the past seven years, not convicted, arrested for a criminal justice system that disproportionately arrest people of color. Punishing someone who has not been found guilty is a true injustice for those who have been convicted.'

'speaker_5': 'The way I see it, you've paid your debt to society if you've served your time. Blocking formerly incarcerated people from accessing stable housing is an extrajudicial punishment and not consistent with the rule of law. It is also a recipe for recidivism and less safety for our communities.'

'speaker_5': 'Recidivism decreases significantly when people get housing with housing. A person is seven times less likely to reenter the criminal justice system. I would expect anyone in favor of a safer. Seattle to support this bill. Further, we're in a homelessness state of emergency.'

'speaker_5': 'If we do not do more to ensure housing providers provide housing for the 55% of unsheltered homeless people in Seattle who identify their criminal background as a barrier to access accessing housing, then we're derelict in our duty to address the homelessness state of emergency.'

'speaker_5': 'In addition, the legislation will not go into effect for nearly six months in order to support a new Fair Housing Home program, in which the city will help landlords learn how they can implement practices that will affirmatively further fair housing by reducing racial and other biases in tenant selection.'

'speaker_5': 'I've heard concerns that with passage of this law and others, that small landlords have been and will continue to leave the business of operating rental housing in a hot real estate market where property put on the market is quickly sold sometimes to developers who charge hard for higher rents after redevelopment.'

'speaker_5': 'I share this concern using a combination of rental registration data as well as county sales records and taxpayer information. Central staff will work to identify the number of properties that have sold over a defined period of time. We can then compare the taxpayer's address with property addresses to get a sense of if it's still a rental.'

'speaker_5': 'I hope to begin some of this work prior to the effective date of the ordinance. AN ORDINANCE authorizing the CEO/General: 'speaker_6': 'Into the agenda item for council bill 1190 36 authorizes the CEO, general manager of Seattle Public Utilities to execute a contract with Cedar Grove composting incorporation for organic waste processing services and ratifying confirming certain prior acts. 'speaker_5': 'Thank you. Compost processing has been performed by.'

'speaker_5': 'Espoo under service contracts with Lenz Enterprises and Pacific Cleanup Washington. These contracts began in April 2014 and continue to March 2020 with optional extensions to March 2024. In 2015, processing operations at Pacific Clean were shut down due to new agricultural regulations, and the company's share of city organic waste has been diverted to a backup facility.'

'speaker_5': 'Cedar Grove Espoo initiated a competitive process for successor services last year. The utility received a competitive proposal in January from Cedar Grove composting and has been negotiating with Pacific Clean and Cedar Grove for successful financial and operational transition.'

'speaker_5': 'This legislation would authorize a new processing contract with Cedar Grove to ensure clean continuity, clean service continuity, while the utility also pursues recovery of outstanding obligations from Pacific Clean. 'speaker_5': 'Lenz Enterprise will continue to successfully process their share of city organic waste through March 2020 or beyond, if desired by the city.'
